fields.summary: [C++] Ensure using "lib/" for jemalloc's library directory

comments.body:
Consequently, I was able to fix this by, during compilation, copying lib64 to lib:

{code:java}
export FOLDER=/tmp/Rtmpqu8Sq9/file5eac6851d0fa # or whatever it is for you
# after 50%, but before before 70%
cp -r $FOLDER/jemalloc_ep-prefix/src/jemalloc_ep/dist/lib64 $FOLDER/jemalloc_ep-prefix/src/jemalloc_ep/dist/lib
{code}

Hope this helps someone.

Thanks for the report, manual intervention like that definitely shouldn't be required. We have CI jobs that ensure that the package works on opensuse 15, but it looks like we don't (yet) have one for opensuse 15.2. I've added one to see if I can reproduce this. I'll keep you posted.

Well, I have run this on our CI (https://dev.azure.com/ursacomputing/crossbow/_build/results?buildId=4160&view=logs&j=0da5d1d9-276d-5173-c4c4-9d4d4ed14fdb&t=d9b15392-e4ce-5e4c-0c8c-b69645229181) and I've also tried installing on a new VM with rstudio/r-base:4.0-opensuse152 (using {{docker run --rm -it rstudio/r-base:4.0-opensuse152 /bin/bash}}. 

Though it looks like the way that has R installed is resulting in a slightly different configuration (for example, your output is looking for R headers at {{/usr/lib64/R/include}}, whereas when I install it's looking for those at {{/opt/R/4.0.4/lib/R/include}}, and on my VM {{/usr/lib/R}} is symlinked to {{/opt/R/4.0.4/lib/R}}. How did you go about installing R? I'm trying to find a way to simulate your environment where it will look in the {{lib64}} version of the directories.

Ultimately, I suspect that we will need to add {{"lib64"}} https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/cpp/cmake_modules/Findjemalloc.cmake#L58 like we've done for a few other dependencies before. But I would love to get a set up that fails without that + then passes with it.

We always build/bundle jemalloc so findjemalloc.cmake shouldn't be relevant (aside: it probably shouldn't exist at all). 

It seems that the issue is that jemalloc (and possibly other bundled dependencies, maybe jemalloc is just the first one not found) is being installed to a lib64 directory but {{ar}} thinks it is in a lib directory. This sounds vaguely familiar to me, and I think there's a *_LIB_DIR we can set explicitly to lib, just not sure all of the places it would need to be wired up (cf. https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/8304/files#diff-5cdc95f4e1b618f2f3ef10d370ce05a1ac05d9d401aecff3ccbb3d76bd366b6aR2672). [~kou] probably knows?
As a workaround while we debug this, you could {{export ARROW_JEMALLOC=OFF}} and reinstall. If jemalloc is the only bundled dependency affected, then it should succeed without it.

It seems that your system overrides the default {{libdir}} by {{/usr/share/site/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu}}.

Renaming the file or applying https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/10139 will fix this case.

Yes:

> grep lib64 /usr/share/site/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
# Use lib64 for 64 bit bi-arch targets, keep the default for the rest.
                libdir='${exec_prefix}/lib64'

Fyi, that file is essentially the same as https://gist.github.com/cszawisza/e3f27b5c84df78cab03c798115a3042f (except for white space and an extra `aarch64`)
